events.title: Adoption of the Declaration of Independence
events.description: The Continental Congress formally adopted the Declaration of Independence, announcing the thirteen American colonies as independent states and no longer a part of the British Empire.
events.significance: Marked the birth of the United States of America and its foundation as a sovereign nation.

events.title: Deaths of John Adams and Thomas Jefferson
events.description: Both John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, the second and third Presidents of the United States and key figures in American independence, died on the same day, the 50th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.
events.significance: Symbolically significant as it connected two founding fathers to the anniversary of America's birth.

events.title: Inauguration of the New York Statue of Liberty's Pedestal
events.description: Construction on the pedestal of the Statue of Liberty was completed, setting the stage for the statue's installation and eventual dedication in 1886.
events.significance: The statue later became a global symbol of freedom and democracy, celebrating American ideals.

events.title: First Launch of Echo 1 Satellite
events.description: The United States launched Echo 1, the first passive communications satellite, to reflect telephone signals, marking an advancement in satellite technology.
events.significance: Pioneered satellite communications, influencing modern telecommunications and global connectivity.
